description: From Middle English diet, dyet, diete, from Old French diete, from Medieval Latin dieta (“regimen, regulation; assembly”), from Latin diaeta, from Ancient Greek δίαιτα (díaita).

entries.meaning: (of a food or beverage) Containing less fat, salt, sugar, or calories than normal, or claimed to have such.

examples: You folks reduce it to the bible only as being authoritative, impoverishing the faith. "Christianity Lite", diet Christianity for those who can't handle the Whole Meal.

entries.meaning: The food and beverage a person or animal consumes.
examples: The diet of the giant panda consists mainly of bamboo.

entries.meaning: (countable) A controlled regimen of food and drink, as to gain or lose weight or otherwise influence health.
(by extension) Any habitual intake or consumption.
examples: He's been reading a steady diet of nonfiction for the last several years.

description: From Middle English dieten, dyeten, diȝeten, from Old French dïeter and Medieval Latin diētāre.

verbs.description: diet (third-person singular simple present diets, present participle dieting, simple past and past participle dieted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To regulate the food of (someone); to put on a diet.
examples: they will diet themselves, feed and live alone.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To modify one's food and beverage intake so as to decrease or increase body weight or influence health.
examples: I've been dieting for six months, and have lost some weight.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To eat; to take one's meals.
(obsolete, transitive) To cause to take food; to feed.

description: From Middle English diet, dyet, from Old French diete, from Medieval Latin diēta, diaeta (“a public assembly; set day of trial; a day's journey”), from Ancient Greek δῐ́αιτα (díaita, “way of living, living space; decision, judgement”), influenced by Latin diēs (“day”).

entries.meaning: (usually capitalized as a proper noun) A council or assembly of leaders; a formal deliberative assembly.
examples: They were given representation of some important diet committees.
Normally the diet begins towards the end of April.

entries.meaning: (Scotland, law) The proceedings under a criminal libel.
(Scotland) A clerical or ecclesiastical function in Scotland.
